items.title: The irreducible extension
items.content:
Minimal viable extension: One capability.
Minimal viable combination: Two extensions that amplify each other.
Everything else: Refinement for specific workflows.

items.title: What if extensions were monolithic?
items.content:
You'd design: One mega-plugin that does everything.
Why this fails: Different workflows need different combinations. One-size-fits-all bloats context.
Hidden constraint revealed: Composability beats completeness.

items.title: Extensions = Unix Philosophy
items.content:
Do one thing well → Each extension provides one capability
Compose via pipes → Stack extensions for workflows
Text as interface → Files and hooks as glue

If you understand Unix, you understand extension composition.

items.title: One constraint -> FIVE decisions
items.content:
ROOT: Claude Code is a single-agent chat interface
-> Need observability? Add Claude HUD
-> Need memory? Add Claude-Mem
-> Need iteration? Add Ralph
-> Need coordination? Add CC Mirror
-> Need external tools? Add MCP servers

items.title: INV-001: Single Responsibility
items.content:
Claude HUD, Claude-Mem, Code-Simplifier, Ralph all share: one extension = one capability.

WHY THIS MATTERS: Combination flexibility requires atomic primitives. Monoliths prevent custom stacks.

items.title: How deep is your understanding?
items.content:
Beginner: "Which extensions should I install?"
Intermediate: "How do I combine them?"
Advanced: "Which pattern (chain/parallel/conditional)?"
Staff: "When is vanilla better?"
Expert: "How do I build custom extensions?"

items.title: Official vs Community Extensions
items.content:
Official: Guaranteed support, slower innovation
Community: Faster innovation, variable quality
Standalone: Maximum flexibility, maintenance burden

Heuristic: Start official, add community when official lacks.

items.title: If you skip marketplace add step
items.content:
IF: Run /plugin install claude-hud directly
THEN: Plugin not found (not in local cache)
THEN: Install fails silently
THEN: You think the plugin doesn't exist

THE FIX: Always /plugin marketplace add THEN /plugin install

items.title: Extension maturity over time
items.content:
Week 1: "Community plugins seem risky"
Month 1: "This community plugin is essential"
Month 3: "The ecosystem is what makes Claude Code powerful"
Month 6: "I'm building my own extensions"

items.title: Sub-Agents Directory: 200+ prompts
items.content: Community-curated directory of agent prompts. Started as informal sharing, now essential resource. Proof that community curation exceeds individual discovery.

items.title: Claude-Mem: 95% token reduction compounds
items.content:
At iteration 1: 5% tokens saved seems minor
At iteration 50: 95% cumulative savings = 20x more tool calls
THRESHOLD: Benefit visible after ~10 sessions with shared context

items.title: How Claude HUD awareness degrades
items.content:
Green (0-50%): Plenty of context, work freely
Yellow (50-80%): Start being selective about what you add
Red (80-95%): Complete current task, don't start new ones
CLIFF (95%+): Context exhausted, restart required

The HUD makes invisible degradation visible.

items.title: Claude-Mem + Ralph
items.content:
Works: Claude-Mem provides cross-session memory. Ralph provides iteration.
Danger: Claude-Mem reads can consume context. Batch get_observations() calls.
Recommendation: Use search() first (compact), get_observations() only for details.

items.title: Code-Simplifier + Ralph Chain
items.content:
Works: Ralph builds feature, code-simplifier polishes before commit.
Why it works: Separation of concerns. Ralph focuses on correctness, simplifier focuses on clarity.
Pattern: Feature Agent -> Test Agent -> Code-Simplifier -> Commit

items.title: CC Mirror = Kubernetes for Agents
items.content:
Orchestrator = Control plane
Agents = Pods
Task dependencies = Service mesh
Blocked tasks = Pending pods

If you understand container orchestration, you understand CC Mirror.

items.title: UNSOLVED: Multi-model routing
items.content:
The question: How to route tasks to optimal model (Opus for reasoning, Sonnet for speed)?
Why it's hard: Need to predict task requirements before execution.
Current practice: Manual model selection. CC Mirror has partial support.

items.title: @weswinder: AGI Stack overnight
items.content: Opus 4.5 + Ralph + Playwright. "The combo reduced my iterations by 3x compared to Sonnet alone. Visual verification caught bugs unit tests missed."

items.title: @TendiesOfWisdom: Context protection
items.content: "Put costly tools like browser control in subagents to protect your main context window tokens." Critical insight for Playwright + Ralph combos.

items.title: When extension count flips benefit to burden
items.content:
1-3 extensions: Pure benefit (each adds capability)
4-6 extensions: Diminishing returns (complexity rising)
7+ extensions: Maintenance burden exceeds value

THE INFLECTION: ~5 extensions
Detection: Spending more time debugging extensions than using them.

items.title: INV-003: External state > internal memory
items.content:
Claude-Mem, Ralph prd.json, progress.txt, Git all share: persistence via files, not LLM memory.

WHY THIS MATTERS: Fresh context requires external state. All composition patterns rely on this invariant.

items.title: Chain vs Parallel Composition
items.content:
Chain: Simple, debuggable, slower
Parallel: Faster, complex coordination, race conditions

Heuristic: Chain for dependent tasks. Parallel only for truly independent work.

items.title: If you don't restart after Claude-Mem install
items.content:
IF: Install Claude-Mem without restarting Claude Code
THEN: Lifecycle hooks don't activate
THEN: Worker service not capturing sessions
THEN: search() returns nothing
FINALLY: You think Claude-Mem is broken

THE FIX: Always restart Claude Code after extension installation.

items.title: What if MCP servers auto-started?
items.content:
You'd expect: Configure once, always works.
Why this fails: Servers crash, env vars change, ports conflict.
Hidden constraint: Manual verification is the reliable path. The "connection refused" error is telling you the truth.

items.title: Hook debugging depth
items.content:
Beginner: "Hooks aren't firing" -> Check settings.json syntax
Intermediate: "Hooks fire twice" -> Multiple extensions registered
Advanced: "Hook order matters" -> Array order = execution order
Staff: "Hooks block each other" -> Consolidate into wrapper script
Expert: "Hook architecture limits" -> Build custom event system

items.title: If extension conflicts are unsolvable
items.content:
Can't resolve hook conflicts? -> Remove one extension, use its features manually
MCP server keeps crashing? -> Use REST API directly via WebFetch
Too many extensions? -> Return to vanilla, add back one at a time

items.title: UNSOLVED: Extension dependency graph
items.content:
The question: How should extensions declare and resolve dependencies?
Why it's hard: Extensions are independent projects. No central registry with version constraints.
Current practice: README instructions. Manual installation order.

items.title: How ecosystem gaps affect productivity
items.content:
100% (no gaps): Theoretical maximum productivity
90% (missing cost tracker): Occasional budget surprises
80% (no rollback): Git reset as workaround
70% (no team collab): Manual knowledge sharing
60% (Windows issues): Platform-specific workarounds

Most teams operate at 70-80% with workarounds.

items.title: Ecosystem maturity perception
items.content:
Day 1: "This ecosystem is immature"
Week 2: "Actually, the gaps have workarounds"
Month 1: "The community is filling gaps faster than I expected"
Month 6: "I'm contributing to the ecosystem now"

items.title: What if you extended everything?
items.content:
You'd install: Every recommended extension immediately.
Why this fails: Configuration overhead. Hook conflicts. Context bloat.
Hidden constraint: Vanilla competence precedes extension mastery. Add one at a time.

items.title: Extension adoption = IDE plugin adoption
items.content:
New IDE user -> Use built-ins first
Intermediate -> Add productivity plugins
Advanced -> Curate minimal essential set
Expert -> Build custom extensions

Same progression applies to Claude Code extensions.

items.title: If extensions aren't for you
items.content:
Need simpler workflow? -> Vanilla Claude Code + good prompts
Need observability without plugins? -> Manual token counting + git log
Need memory without Claude-Mem? -> CLAUDE.md + manual updates
Need iteration without Ralph? -> Manual bash loops

items.title: Extension mastery compounds
items.content:
At 1 extension: Incremental benefit
At 3 extensions: Workflow automation emerging
At 5 extensions: Custom development environment
At custom extension: You're now part of the ecosystem

Each mastered extension unlocks new combination possibilities.
